My favourite thing about your music is that your lyrics are so interpretable. They might seem random to some but I've always felt they are just specific enough to be applied many different scenarios, usually someone who is going on some kind of journey. Personally, I've often noticed transgender themes that seem to be present in your lyrics. In both And The Day Goes On and Outside you talk about changing your name, and When I Get Older has that lyric about changing your face. I've also clocked similar themes of understanding identity and leaving previous lives behind in order to explore things that are considered taboo in songs like Mount St. Helens, We Could Just Get High, I'm Best Friends With My Own Front Door, Movie Star, and It's Gonna Be Alright (I could list specific examples but it would take too long). What is the real meaning behind this line?

here's what i think, as i'm analyzing it now: this is a classic case of the song being about itself. The starting point for that song was just the one line ('just did a bad thing'), with really no indication of any sort of form or anything. Half way through the first section, it already seems to ditch out of the original paradigm slightly ('wondering what it is, etc'), it slips into the major key, and just,... no sort of repeating figure has been established. so far everything seems to be a special-case scenario. Then when it hits the next stanza, (bad day, bad year), we've already broken from what it had done in the first stanza. (the first stanza had the 'regret' line, which is quite different from the first line, but in the second stanza, the first two lines essentially are the same as each other), so for many reasons, at this point, (after 'bad year'), it's very clear that there is NO established pattern. we are free to roam. And it's likely at this point that i was feeling stuck, because really there's just too many possibilities. I was probably running through what i had so far, thinking i would get clues about the future (of the song) from the past (in the song). And that's just not gonna happen, because really what should probably happen is it should probably get out and GO somewhere it hasn't gone yet. So, looking at what did come next, the 'cancelled' line, this is a perfect way of expressing that everything you might have expected was going to happen (based on what happened so far) in the song, will probably not happen. And, sure enough, immediately after this, it transitions into a totally new key, and a new paradigm entirely. So basically the reason for that line is to shake off the previous paradigm (bad things, etc), because we gotta get away and jump into a whole new territory. (the 'game' section, etc).
As far as anything having resemblence to future world events, well, this is always more likely to happen the more songs i write. when making a case that something predicted something, you can always ignore the ones that didn't fit. such as 'at the airport terminal' which certainly does not predict 2020

and what advice would you give to a budding bass player?

basically you want to get yourself as soon as possible into a role where you are providing the bass for a song. if you can't get together with other people to play together, (and most people probably can't), just go ahead and take your favorite song recordings and cut out the bass frequencies, and plug your bass into a speaker which DOES have bass frequencies, and play along. 
Examples of speakers with and without bass frequencies, so you know which ones to use for which-- 

has bass frequencies: bass amp, headphones, home stereo system
does not have bass frequencies: laptop speaker, phone speaker, tablet speaker, speakers inside your computer monitor

play the song on the speaker with no bass, and put your bass through a speaker with bass. now you are the bass player

i keep having ideas when it's hard to write them down (shower etc.) and if i do go to write the idea down i usually forget most of the details. and if i deliberately put myself into a situation where i can easily write things down (usually by having my ideas document open or by using an audio recorder), then i can't have ideas. it feels like it's only possible for me to either have ideas or remember them, but not both.

that's true, ideas come most easily when they would be harder to write down. There are 2 strategies for the shower. one strategy, if you think the idea is really that good, just get out of the shower and go write it down. Or, if you don't want to do that, here are some memory tricks. pretend you are explaining the idea to someone else, and start explaining it in as many technical ways as you can. Pretend you have to explain it to them so that they can reproduce the idea exactly, but, you are not allowed to actually demonstrate it. For example, if it's a sentence, say "the first word is ___, the second word is ____," etc... Count the words. remind yourself how many words there are. Say all the odd numbered words. Say all the even numbered words. Think of the first letter of each word, and put all those letters together. try to come up with an alternate sentence using the same starting letters. Try to access the idea in as many different ways as you can. If it is a musical idea, start thinking of the notation of it, imagine you are explaining the musical notation to someone else without singing it. List the notes in order. Count the notes. List the rhythmic values in order. If you don't know musical notation in this way, hopefully you have some other conceptual notation system you use to think about notes and time. What tempo is it? what song has a similar tempo? how many notes are in the first beat? how many notes are in the second beat? etc etc etc. Keep trying to access the idea on as many mental avenues as you can, and this will increase the likelyhood that you will be able to retrieve it. but really the best option is to just get out of the shower. Most other places besides the shower, try to carry a recording device with you, the most common one being a smart phone. and if you have that, then much of these techniques will not be necessary

why was the time between the draft composition/writing of "and the day goes on" and its release date 699 days?

i will explain the timeline so hopefully it will make sense. in march 2015, the instrumental idea for the verse occured to me. i was not expecting it, it was not a planned 'writing session'. This is how many songs get started, they drop out of the sky, so you have to get good at catching them. So, (ref: 20150331.mp4"target="_blank)this is me catching it. (march 2015). Sure, i could have immediately gone into a writing session for that idea, but, why not instead for an idea i had had the previous day? or a video idea i had had the previous day? it is always raining ideas. There is always more to be done than there is time to do. In march 2015 i had developed a 2 pronged approach: 2 short videos per week, and 'everything else'. I was doing 2 short videos per week just to have something to release, then in between, move forward on longer projects. I had a randomized selection scheme to help choose which longer projects to do. Near to that time, the 'crazy/raining' song was selected. That took several weeks. After that, it was the 'free to do whatever you want to' song. This took even longer. What also was happening at the same time was, my short videos had taken off on the vine platform. So i had made the decision to start vinifying my entire video catalog starting with the earliest, and posting them to vine every day. Around august (2015) i reached the end of the catalog so i had to make a decision about what to do going forward. i decided the vines were doing so well that it became important to make 7 new ones per week. This was unfortunate for my longer video aspirations, because it pretty much meant zero time leftover to pursue that. but it was important to keep things rolling on vine. So i carried on like this for about 2 more months, but my desire to make long videos was getting even more intense. I discovered a trick, where i could spend the first half of the day working on a long video, and not start the vine until the second half of the day, which forced me to do them much quicker. so i started on history of japan (oct 2015). i continued on like this, doing short videos while doing a long video, and finally around january i was getting into the scoring process (final stage) of the japan video and  decided that i should pause the vines in order to finish the japan video more quickly. japan was finished by late january, it went to youtube and did very well there. i took this as a chance to put together a project i had always really really wanted to do but never found time: to make videos out of journal edits. i had about 6 years of audio journal content, and i combed through it as best i could, making video edits to attempt to chronicle my journey. After about 2 months working on this, i really had to cut it short because it was going on way too long. so i really only got to do about 10% of what i wanted. Also the other half of that project was for improv footage. I had to cut that way way short because no regular videos were being done during this time. So i only got a chance to do maybe 2% of the improv edits i wanted to do. So finally around May (2016) i was ready to get back to regular videos. there was so much i wanted to do, and didn't even know where to begin. I started extremely short, as i normally do, with a plan to make them gradually longer. I started making an agenda list of the sequence of upcoming items, and i wanted to include some medium length songs. Choosing from a list of hundreds, one of the ones i chose was that instrumental chord sequence back from march 2015. So i wrote that into a full song, over a couple of days. this song was called 'and the day goes on.' Among other short videos, there was also another song that i selected at that time, for release soon after. which i also wrote fully at that time. called 'hallelujah'. we are around june 2016 now. Then, suddenly, i felt a lot of public outrage that i was 'still doing short videos', and to be honest, i agreed with it. I also had a pent up desire to do an even more bombastic history project than the japan one, so i changed the plans, cancelled the remaining short-medium projects, and started on history of the entire world. Something you may or may not know about the history of the world- the world has a lot of history. so, to put it all into 1 video is probably impossible, so i knew i was taking on something that might be impossible. but i wanted to do it anyway. so first i had to *learn* the history of the entire world. which also takes a long time. research and writing took all summer, and i reached the end of the writing by about September 7, 2016. One of the things i had been thinking during the writing process, is a 2D equirectangular projected map is probably not gonna work for this. i should really get it on a 3D globe. but i didn't have the tools for that. so during most of september i was experimenting with various 3D tools to try to meet my 3D needs. i also began going through and developing the images that would be needed for the video, while also making many changes to the script. By the end of october i had most of this squared away, and around November 1st i was ready to begin the full video production. At this point i was determined to reach the end of the entire project by december 1st, and i nearly destroyed myself throughout november trying to meet this. but toward the end of november i realized this wasn't even close to possible. so i continued through december, through many of the most challenging parts of the video production, especially having to correct some problems with the 3D globe animations (which had been first done in october). finally made it to the end of the visual production by about february 7 (2017), and began on recording the final narration, and doing the final jingles, and then finally doing the score. the video was finally finished around may 10, 2017. By this time i knew very well that i really just need to do songs for the rest of my life. So i decided to skip the videos and just do audio songs, 1 per week. this went ok, but i soon realized that videos are very important. so around late june (2017) i started on 2 projects simultaneously: a freeform non-song video (hi, i'm steve) and a music video for one of the recently released audio songs (movie star). Working on 2 things at once is usually a recipe for failure, so i did then one at a time. steve first, then movie star. Then onward, to the next music video, 'outside'. this took about 6 weeks. I've never been pleased by the amount of time it takes to do these things. my prefered target for music videos would be 1 week, but to this day i've never been able to accompish this. Nearing the end of the 'outside' project, in late september (2017), i made a demand of myself that i MUST do these in 2 weeks. and i also felt it was necessary to do non-songs as well. So, alternate betwen non-songs and songs, and also, 1 out of every 2 songs should have live performance footage. So the next item would be a non-song, and, because i was able to make it shorter, i was able to do it just barely in 2 weeks. this was called 'soap tips' and was completed around oct 10, 2017. The next thing would have to be a song, and it would have to include live performance footage. Unfortunately this shattered all previous records for how long a music video should take, and this is probably because i hadn't appeared in live performance footage in such a long time that i couldn't stop myself from being incredibly particular for how things appear. i was horrified by the fact that that project ultimately took exactly the same amount of time as history of japan had taken (98 days, or 14 weeks.) it was finally completed in january, 2018. the target of course was 2 weeks, but that was a hopeless failure. So my next revision of the plan, would be to do 2 weeks per video, but they don't have to be a song. because i knew song videos would take longer, probably because my standards for how long a song should be were somewhere around 2:30 to 3:30, where as the non-song videos could be as short as 1 minute or maybe even less. so i decided to just try 1 video per 2 weeks, not necessarily a song. I was able to succeed at this, just barely, with 2 non-song videos. But, of course, as fate would have it, i realized songs are incredibly important. So i decided to do a song next, i already knew i wanted to do 'and the day goes on', because that one had its writing completed (in 2016) and i thought it was a strong one that i was confident about. I decided 4 weeks would be a sensible target for that. it was an especially elegant target, because it was february, and in that year (most years) februrary is exactly 4 weeks, so that would put the release date on exactly the same day of the month as the previous. Unfortunately that proved again to be impossible. and it never helps that my standards usually continue to go up. I was very meticulous on most parts of the process. i finally was able to complete the video around april 25, 2018. i immediately moved on to start the next song project. It's worth mentioning what happens next, because that will help bring this into even more perspective for you. At the start of every song process, i first do a generalized idea having process, where i come up with brand new ideas for songs. I usually do about 5 or 10, THEN the song selection process begins, where those new ideas are put into the much larger pool of unfinished songs, and i select from the entire list. It looks like there were 9 new ideas created on april 26 and 27, 2018. What ended up being selected, for the next song, was none of those, it was one that was already in the broader list ('hello sexy pants'). But, of those new 9, many of those have been extremely strong contenders every time since, with many of them almost getting picked, and one of them being 'when i get older' which was picked later that year. To get back to your original question, i think one of the strongest factors in play here is the fact that it is impossible to do everything at the same time, although that would be extremely convenient for me

'maybe i could eat blades of grass' seems to have this weirdly defeated tone in comparison to your other stuff. the intro sets up a questioning vibe, and the question turns out to be 'why is everything so dumb and stupid';and after some excursions and attempts at looking at some things in the real world, all of which we've actually done, it seems like we come to actually admit that the hypothesis is true: everything is stupid. (which is interesting, because that's technically not the question that was asked;that's a reaffirmation of what the question presumed to be true already in its phrasing, that everything was stupid. but it also might be an answer to the question anyway, in the stupidest possible way: everything is stupid because it's stupid. that's a pretty stupid answer, which seems about right.) the 'rock in a plaid shirt' part seems to be a kind of last-ditch effort at something that isn't stupid, something new, but it all goes w rong, an d it sounds like (with the falling pitches and the final kick drum hit on 'stupid') that the end of blades of grass really was meant to be an admission of defeat. 

i just thought this was odd considering that you seem to be a fan of stupid;the two 'stupid songs' you've made seem to suggest you think stupidity can get you to stronger songs, videos, etc. but in blades of grass it seems like stupidity stands for a lack of meaning, and there's no way you're trying to say that nothing means anything - that's like the ultimate anti-bill wurtz sentiment as far as i can tell. let me know if any of this seems comprehensible to you. thanks

ik this is a tired type of question, but whats the inspiration/meaning behind your video Time Mop? it's very different than other things you were making at the time and gives off some weird vibes.

there are 2 elements to that, which came about completely separately. the audio, and the video that goes with it. The audio recording, called "time mop", was part of a series of 4 recordings i made in june 2009. my career felt way way too speculative for many years up until then, and i was getting very desperate to actually make some recordings. so in a fit of rage and desperation, i did "help, i'm trapped in the center of a rectangle", and 3 others, including "time mop". those are just instrumental music pieces, with no video. 
Then, later, around 2014, after i had finally begun actually making videos, sometimes song-videos, one of the types of videos i was doing would be music videos to go with songs i had already recorded. i had done some of these already, and they all were songs with lyrics. When there's lyrics, it usually gives you a pretty obvious guide for what might happen in the video. But, what if it's an entirely instrumental song? what would the video look like then? So i decided to try. Actually, i just remembered, i had actually begun to do work on this video as early as 2013, in the early stages of experimenting with video. and then i picked it up again after the regular video production schedule was underway. So it was originally an instrumental, in 2009, as a challenge to myself to do ANYTHING (besides textual non-video non-music), and the video in 2013 was a challenge to see if i could do a music video for a song without lyrics

if you wouldn't mind temporarily stepping out of the mindset of producing your newest and soon-too-be-hopefully-greatest song and video, is there any song you've made in the past that stands out to you in any way;

and if so, would you have any thoughts you could share?

on 'hallelujah', i decided to START the entire recording process on an EQ setting that mimics the speaker on a smartphone. the reason i did this was to try to have a better guarantee that the arrangement would make sense there (literally no bass). it sometimes stresses me out that that platform is so drastically different from the ones that include the bass (headphones, car speakers, etc). It's almost like if you are doing a TV show and 40% of your audience can't see the color green. If you are making the project on a system where you CAN see the color green, you're gonna have no idea what those greenless viewers are even seeing. Some people check different systems at the very end, and then make 'adjustments', but i figured it's way too late if you check it at the end. so i decided to start the entire process in the bassless mode, to make sure i was making decisions that were strong on that platform. Then turn the bass frequencies back on and then fill in the bass i want for the full-range listeners. This seemed like a good idea but it didn't really go so well and i don't do it anymore. it didn't really harm the sound of the song, but it encouraged me to overthink even more than i normally do
